detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Celebrity Studies critically analyzes global celebrity, stardom, and mediated performance. Drawing upon film and media studies, social and cultural theory, and philosophy, this course examines key films and readings to help define and interrogate the phenomenon of modern celebrity.

If this section if FULL or BLOCKED please sign up for the corresponding waitlist section. Once you have registered in the wait list there is no need to contact the department. Your registration will be switched to the parent section when space becomes available. Preference may be given to Majors, Minors, or Honours students in Theatre or Film. For more information about Department of Theatre and Film wait lists please visit: http://theatrefilm.ubc.ca/undergraduate/undergraduate-courses/how-to-wait-list-a-course/

instances.text: THTR_V 205-A_001 - Graphics for Theatre and Film Design (A)

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Students must register in one of the available lab sections, L01 or L04. 

Unlock Your Creative Expression: The Art of Visual Storytelling
In an increasingly interconnected and visually-driven world, effective communication goes beyond words and speeches. Whether you're an aspiring scientist, engineer, business professional, or artist, our course in Visual Storytelling offers a unique opportunity to explore the captivating realm of non-verbal expression.

instances.text: THTR_V 210-001 - Drama: Forms and Ideas I

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
THTR 210 Drama: Forms and Ideas I

THTR 210 is an introduction to the study of dramatic literature, with a particular focus on western theatrical traditions from the fifth century BCE to the eighteenth century CE. The course contextualizes the plays read in their original cultural and socio-political context, while teaching students how to read these plays as texts which encode performance. We will examine original performance conventions tied to each play that we study, but we will also consider how these plays have been reperformed in later periods. The classes consist of two large-scale lectures on Mondays and Wednesdays and a smaller discussion-based class each Friday. This is an introductory course and students are not expected to have a background in theatre, either in reading dramatic literature or in thinking about plays in performance.

NOTE: You must also register in a corresponding Discussion Section (D11, D12, D13). If this section is FULL or BLOCKED please sign up for the corresponding wait list section. Once you have registered in the wait list there is no need to contact the department. Your registration will be switched to the parent section when space becomes available. Preference may be given to Majors, Minors, or Honours students in Theatre or Film. For more information about Department of Theatre and Film wait lists please visit: http://theatrefilm.ubc.ca/undergraduate/undergraduate-courses/how-to-wait-list-a-course/

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
If you have previously taken stage craft classes or have been a part of backstage theatre production, the THTR 150 pre-req may be waived. Please email the instructor to request waiving the pre-req.

Please note, this section is for studio time from 9-12pm on Friday mornings. The Thursday class time is the same as section 002. 

If you are unable to register for this course but are interested in enrolling, please email the instructor. This course replaces THTR 254.

If you are unable to register for this course but are interested in enrolling, please email the instructor. This course replaces THTR 254.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
This course is for practicum assignments for Scene Shop Build Crew, Prop Shop Build Crew, and Show Run Crew. 
Prop Shop Hours: Monday-Thursday, 9-1pm
Scene Shop Hours: Monday - Thursday (Term 1), 1-5pm; Monday - Friday (Term 2), 1-5pm

*All scene shop hours completed in the Frederic Wood Theatre shops. Show Run Crew schedule will adhere to production schedule.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
UKRN 225 is meant for students who have already completed UKRN 125 or its equivalent, or are intermediate speakers of the language.  Do you have a connection to the Ukrainian nation? Curious to know about Ukrainian language and culture? Want to stand with Ukraine in the struggle for its sovereignty and the peaceful democratic future of the world? It's time to turn your dreams into reality! This 6-credit course will help you build confidence in communicating in a language which is quite different from Germanic and Romance languages as well as introduce you to the life of contemporary Ukraine, its rich culture and history. 

Interested in other courses within the Department of Central, Eastern and Northern European Studies? Click here.

uiLabels.WDRES.FACETEDSEARCH.SymanSyntax:
Boolean logic can be expressed using AND, OR, NOT, and (). 
Exact phrases can be surrounded by double quotation marks. 
Example: ("software engineer" OR computer science) AND ~manager~.
